definition: Research papers that are freely available to read online without a paywall or subscription. Anyone can access the full text immediately.
A barrier that requires payment (often $30+) or institutional access to read a research paper. This limits who can verify the science.
A process where other experts in the field evaluate a research paper before publication to check its quality and validity.
An early version of a research paper shared publicly before peer review. Useful for rapid communication but not yet vetted by experts.
When researchers make their raw data publicly available so others can verify results and conduct their own analyses.
The number of participants or observations in a study. Larger samples generally provide more reliable results.
A comparison group that doesn't receive the treatment being tested, used to determine if an intervention actually works.
Correlation means two things happen together; causation means one causes the other. Correlation does NOT prove causation.
Declaring your research plan and analysis methods publicly before collecting data, which reduces bias and questionable research practices.
A publication that accepts papers without proper peer review, often charging fees. These journals prioritize profit over scientific quality.
Repeating a study to see if the same results occur. Replicable findings are more trustworthy than one-off results.
A measure of whether results are likely due to chance or represent a real effect. Typically set at p < 0.05, but context matters.
